title.rendered: Minecraft: modes, platforms, updates and PC system requirements at a glance

Minecraft was released in May 2009 by the Swedish studio Mojang and later implemented on other platforms. In the open world game, you build a world of blocks alone or with friends, with almost no creative limits. Here you can get information about the modes, platforms, updates and PC system requirements.


Minecraft is an open world game from the developer studio Mojang. (Source: Microsoft)

In May 2009, the then indie development studio Mojang released the open world game Minecraft for the PC. Implementations for the Xbox 360, Xbox One, PS3, PS4, Nintendo Wii U, Nintendo Switch, New Nintendo 3DS and PS Vita followed. The game has also been implemented for iOS, Android, Apple TV, Amazon Fire TV, Raspberry Pi and Windows Phone. The content of the game varies from platform to platform.

That’s what Minecraft is all about

Minecraft focuses primarily on the aspect of playful creativity. Alone or with friends, you build all kinds of buildings, structures and even entire cities out of blocks in an open game world. A sophisticated programming system (which works using the Redstone resource in the game) offers players a wide range of applications. The game also has a combat system, NPCs (non-player characters) and its own servers.

What is special is that players are offered a gigantic world with almost infinite resources. At the beginning, however, the player starts without any form of items or equipment. The core element of Minecraft is the crafting system, which allows objects such as tools, torches, weapons or building materials such as fences, blocks of wood or carpets to be produced from collected resources. In some modes there are opponents that can harm and even kill the player.

The different game modes

There are different modes to choose from in Minecraft. In creative mode, players cannot take damage and have infinite resources. The focus here is on the creative aspect of the game. In survival mode, resources are limited and the player must defend himself against opponents such as zombies and skeletons. Regular food intake is also required. In the event of death, he loses all items he is carrying and restarts from his last save point (spawn point). The hardcore mode is a harder form of the survival variant, which differs by an unchangeable level of difficulty and a deletion of the game world in case of death.

Adventure Mode is a variant of Survival Mode, in which only certain actions can be performed. It is primarily intended for playing together on servers in order to prevent certain actions by other players. So-called command blocks for individual program commands are also used here. In spectator mode, the player acts passively, cannot influence the world, but can walk through walls and fly.

Minecraft in multiplayer

Minecraft allows interaction with other players both on LAN and online via private and official servers. Hosts can restrict the rights of fellow players. On some of these servers, many players build their own worlds together, others offer special mini-games that are based on Battlefield or The Hunger Games, for example.

Updates, mods and additional content

The various versions of Minecraft are regularly updated by the developer with patches and updates and are provided with new free content. In addition, paid content such as texture packs or DLCs can be purchased on some platforms. On the computer-based versions, players also have access to a variety of mods, texture packs, graphical enhancement tools, and additional content created by other players.
